Description: Limestone plaque with a naked female figure standing inside a portico. She wears a short wig that has been painted black. Her facial features are now worn. She is depicted nude, with a narrowed waist and slightly pronounced belly. Her pubic area is delineated with black paint, and her elongated arms are held by her sides. On her left side at the portico’s wall appears to be an image of a mirror and handle outlined in black paint, with the upper part of the mirror now faded. There are also traces of a blue paint on this part of the portico. On either side of the figure are two Hathor-headed capitals, again with black paint used to detail their wigs. The faces of both of these Hathor heads are also worn, and no features can be discerned. The sides and reverse of the plaque are blank. The edges of the portico and the figure’s legs are damaged. The object is now supported on a modern base.
Curator's comments: The portico was clearly painted with further decoration and colours, but these have now faded. The rendering of the female body, with the rounded breasts and slight paunch of the stomach, may point towards a later date in the first millennium BC.
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
